unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Binomial Applications
question_text:
A student is taking a $10\text{ question}$ multiple choice test that has five options for each question (A, B, C, D, and E).
Suppose a student knows the correct answer to $6$ of the questions. For the remaining $4\text{ questions}$, the student can eliminate one response per question, on average.
What is the probability the student gets at least an $80\%$ on the test?
solution:
To get at least an $80\%$, the student must guess at least $2$ of the $4\text{ questions}$ correct. Since the student can eliminate $1$ of the answers, $\text{P(success)} = \frac{1}{4} = 0.25$.

$\text{P(x = 8) = P(guess 2 correct)} = 0.25^2 \cdot 0.75^2 \cdot { { _{ 4 }C_{ 2 } } }$
$\text{P(x = 9) = P(guess 3 correct)} = 0.25^3 \cdot 0.75^1 \cdot { { _{ 4 }C_{ 1 } } }$
$\text{P(x = 10) = P(guess 4 correct)} = 0.25^4 \cdot 0.75^0 \cdot { { _{ 4 }C_{ 0 } } }$

Add these up to get $0.2617$.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.
